paper_title.en: Seasonal changes of wood formation and some characteristics of heartwood formation in teak(┣DBTectona(/)-┫DB ┣DBgrandis(/)-┫DB L. )plantation
Seasonal characteristics of wood formation in Hopea odorata and Shorea henryana

description.en: Seasonal characteristics of wood formation were investigated using the pinning method in Hopea odorata and Shorea henryana in a natural dry evergreen forest of eastern Thailand. The position of cells having initiated S-1-layer formation at the time of pinning was estimated in the zone where cells were directly injured by the pinning and consequently destroyed. The position of cambial initials at the time of pinning was estimated in the zone where cells were indirectly affected by the pinning and continued their physiological activity resulting in the formation of aberrant cells. Traumatic resin canals were occasionally formed in Shorea. These canals were formed after pinning and could, therefore, not record the exact time of the pinning. Diameter growth of both species was greatest in the rainy season and decreased in the dry season.

paper_title.en: Trace elements in the stems of trees VI Comparisons of radial distributions among hard wood stems.
Trace elements in the stems of trees V. Comparisons of radial distributions among softwood stems.
AN APPLICATION OF THE PINNING METHOD TO THE MARKING OF THE DIFFERENTIATING ZONE AND TO THE ESTIMATION OF THE TIME-COURSE OF ANNUAL RING FORMATION IN SUGI (CRYPTOMERIA-JAPONICA)

description.en: On the trunk bf sugi (Cryptomeria japonica D. Don) trees, a pinning method was applied to investigate the possibility of marking xylem growth, especially the sites of cambial initials and each stage of the differentiating zone at a certain time in the past. Estimations of the sites of cambial initials and cells of the initiations of S1 layer formation and S3 layer formation became possible from observations under an ordinary light microscope and a polarizing microscope of the cell wall structures which suffered direct effects of pinning injuries. Seasonal characteristics of the differentiating zones were investigated from observations and measurements of the pinned parts. It was clarified that the time necessary for cell differentiation was about 30 days in the early wood formation period. The transitional stage of early wood to late wood judged from Mork's definition was the end of June. The tangential wall thickness of tracheids, moreover, was thicker than that of the radial wall in the early wood formation period, but this tendency was reversed in late wood.
